name: Connor
comment info: I notice in the graph that financial factors appear to be the most important for both 16-19 year-olds and college grads. Affordable tuition and income potential have the greatest relative importance for both groups. For 16-19 year-olds, the school type (public/private) is the least important factor and varsity sports importance is the least important factor for college grads. I also notice that the factors with the greatest difference in importance between 16-19 year-olds and college grads are small class sizes and distance to family. For distance to family, the relative importance is about 1/4 less than it is for 16-19 year-olds. For small class sizes, the relative importance is around 1/3 lower for 16-19 year-olds than it is for graduates. I wonder why college graduates value being near family less than 16-19 year-olds. I wonder if this is because college graduates have become accustomed to living away from family and are now more comfortable or adjusted, and thus value distance to family/hometown less. Being a college student personally, I can relate to this and I believe those around me prioritize the same factors outlined in this, namely college affordability and income potential, as these can directly influence an individuals choice to attend a particular school or pursue a particular degree. How University Priorities Shift Before and After College

name: Hailey Ernest
comment info: From the graph, I noticed that “Affordable tuition” is the criterion that’s most prioritized for both high school students and college graduates, with graduates placing slightly higher importance on it. This indicates a shared concern over the financial burden of education. The gap in priorities is noticeable in the criteria of proximity to family or hometown and class sizes, with younger students placing more emphasis on family and older students placing more emphasis on quality of education. This indicates that as students mature and experience college life, their perspective on values shifts, showed by gaining appreciation for independence and personalized attention that smaller classes provide. I wonder how representative this data is across different demographics and if these priorities shift with cultural background, economic status, or region. I wonder where the surveyed 2,000 young people between the ages of 16 and 19 and the other 2,000 college graduates between the ages of 22 and 30 came from (specific city/state/county). As a college student myself, within a community that student debt is common, the importance of affordable tuition resonates deeply. The preference for small class sizes aligns with my personal educational experience at Cal Poly, where engagement and personalized feedback have been beneficial. A catchy headline that captures what’s going on in this graph is "Dollars and Diplomas: Students Share Stance on the Price of Learning".

name: Arneh Begi
comment info:
I've noticed that affordable tuition stands out as the top priority for recent college graduates and 16-19 year olds alike, which makes perfect sense considering the aversion to attending an unaffordable college. Additionally, it's notable that 16-19 year olds place greater emphasis on proximity to family or hometown when choosing a college. Understandably, embarking on such a significant life transition prompts a desire to remain connected to familiar surroundings. In contrast, college graduates are more seasoned and accustomed to the college environment.
It's intriguing to ponder how long it takes for 16-19 year olds to adjust to college life and reassess their priorities, particularly regarding proximity to family or hometown. Personally, I can relate to this experience, as I, too, initially hesitated to venture far from home for college. The first few weeks away from my accustomed lifestyle were met with skepticism, yet over time, I adapted and discovered newfound independence.
A compelling headline capturing this transition could be "Pre-College vs. Post-College Priorities: Navigating the Shift."

name: Daniel Tsemekhman
comment info: As a college student, this graph comparing what high school students and recent grads prioritize in choosing a college is eye-opening. Affordability and future income potential dominate for both, which makes sense but is also concerning. High schoolers care way more about being close to home, while grads value small class sizes - perspectives that seem to shift after experiencing college firsthand. I wonder if grads had some huge impersonal lectures that made them appreciate smaller discussions and professor relationships. As someone still in college, this makes me reflect on how my own priorities have evolved and will likely keep changing. A headline could be: "College Priorities: How Perspectives Shift from Application to Graduation." Overall, this shows the value of colleges connecting applicants with recent alumni insights. It has me thinking more deeply about what factors will matter most to me by the time I graduate.

name: Colin Hassett
comment info:
The first thing I notice is that the gap between 16-19 year-olds prioritizing "near family or hometown" more than recent college grads. It stuck out to me because after going to college myself, I felt I enjoyed the convenience of being able to drive home, as opposed to being forced to fly. It seems like before college, people may find it scary to go so far from home for the first time. After college, it seems less scary to move away from your family. One thing I wonder is why there is a gap between "whether the school is public or private" between the college grads and 16- to 19-year-olds. Comparatively, they both feel nearly the same about affordable tuition. Since private schools tend to cost more than in-state public schools, I wonder if both groups surveyed had the financial aspect in mind when considering public vs private schools. I also wonder if one group preferred public schools or private schools more than the other.
This relates to me as someone who went to a school by almost complete chance, and realized that things I thought were important at first are less important now that I'm in college. I think a good headline for this graph might be "Change in Priorities: What College Grads Would Prioritize When Looking for a College"

name: Kailyn
comment info:
What I Noticed

I noticed that 16-19 year olds and recent college graduates share the same perspective on which matters the most during college. Both groups see affordable tuition as the most significant, followed by graduate's potential for higher income. I also noticed the wide gap between the responses of the two groups when it comes to the importance of class sizes. Compared to 16-19 year olds, recent graduates see more importance in class sizes, which would make sense. Most college students would understand the long wait during office hours.

What I Wonder

I wonder if 16-19 year olds have changed their perspective on the importance of class size after attending college.

How does this relate to you and your community?

As a current college student, I would say reports like these would be beneficial and informative to incoming college students when choosing their university. Looking back, I probably would have had similar priorities to 16-19 year olds.

Headline

The College I Wish I Chose - Learning From Graduates

name: Warren Woo
comment info: The first thing I noticed was the two largest gaps between the college hopefuls and the graduates. I think it makes a lot of sense that graduates would value being closer home less compared to the hopefuls. The hopefuls will most likely want to hold onto the friends that they have already made in high school and be scared of becoming more independent which is why they would want to stay close to home, however the graduates, after already going through college have already made new friends and have become independent, so they realized that being away from their hometown might have actually been a good thing. The other great difference comes with valuing small classes. It also makes a lot of sense that high schoolers, who probably haven't experienced big lecture classes, wouldn't value the small class sizes as much because they don't know. In the case for the graduates, because they already went through college, they were able see why having small classes is nice relative to big lecture classes. One thing I wonder is if the students they surveyed were just students from the United States. I would be interested in learning if this graph reflects students internationally. As a current college student, I can most definitely reflect a lot of what the graduates value, especially the small class sizes. A title I would give this graph is "A Reflection of Priorities, What do you Value?"

replies.name: D

name: Luke Thilmony
comment info:
The first thing I noticed were the largest bars or the categories that the graduates and prospective students disagree on the most. I find it interesting that the 16-19 year old didn't values small class sizes as much as recent graduates, probably because recent graduates have more experience in huge class sizes and found that they disliked them. I wonder what exactly relative importance means. This is closely related to me because I am currently a college student and i think about how some of these things affect me currently. Something like varsity sports, which I thought I didn't really care about I have found that I care even less about the longer I attend college.
Headline: "What do incoming and outgoing students value for college?"

name: Ethan
comment info: The first thing I notice is that the axis is extremely confusing.  What I think the graph measures is that something is ___ times as likely to be on a response than the average response. But still, I am actually confused what this graph shows. I wonder what the bolding means on the axis. I also wonder why on the axis there are only two ticks right of the average but four to the left of the average. This relates to me because as a soon to be graduated college student, I really relate to the answers of the recent college graduates. I see myself also in the orange responses earlier in my life, but as I have gotten older I definitely care more about being near family and less about sports. A possible headline is “College student priorities: Its not all about partying!”.

name: Donya
comment info: It seems like there are three categories where the 16-19 year olds and 22-30 year olds tend to agree the most. First, affordable tuition is highly important to both age groups (above 4x relative importance). This makes sense for those considering college, as they would most likely want to attend a school that is affordable for them or their families. This is similar for those who had attended college and may want to go to graduate school or those who simply want their children’s college tuition to be reasonably priced as well. In addition to tuition, it looks like graduates’ higher income potential as well as racial and ethnic diversity closely align in importance between both age groups. In terms of the college being near family/hometown and class sizes, this is where the groups differ the most in their opinions. I wonder who the survey targeted. Was this a convenience sample? A random sample? Can we make generalizations about a larger population with this sample? I’m currently a college student finishing up my third year, so it’s interesting to see how graduates’ opinions change after attending college. I wonder if my opinions will be any different as well. As of now, I would highly consider higher income potential, racial and ethnic diversity, and the college having a safe campus if I had to make a decision on what school to go to. A catchy headline could be: “Decisions, decisions: How opinions of college considerations change before and after attending university”

replies.name: K
replies.comment info: Hi Donya, I really like that you asked whether this sample is a convenience sample. This wont really be generalizable to larger populations if it is.

name: Deven
comment info:
I notice that for both 16-19 year olds and recent college graduates, the consensus most important aspect of choosing a college is the tuition fees and how affordable they are. I also notice that the biggest difference in opinions occur for class sizes. Graduated students appreciated the idea of smaller classes while the college students to be accept the idea of larger class and lecture halls. I notice that for graduate students, being close to family or a hometown is much less important. I think this is because when first leaving the house, the idea of being independent can be scary for 16 to 19 year olds which could result in timidness when thinking about going far from home.

I wonder if the priority of having a safe campus will ever over take affordable tuition as the number one priority. Now more than ever there has been lots of violence, especially gun violence, at colleges across America and at some point people may be forced to put their safety over the cost of schools. I also wonder that if for this particular group, if you were to give the current 16 to 19 year olds the same survey when they're graduate students, how they would change after having collegiate experience.

This relates to me and my community because as a college student just a few years ago me and my peers were forced to answer these very questions when deciding out schools. For me, tution and class sizes played the biggest factors in my decision.

"Does Experience Change Priorities: College Edition"

name: Deven
comment info:
In the graph, I notice that for both 16-19 year olds and recent college graduates, the consensus most important aspect of choosing a college is the tuition fees and how affordable they are. I also notice that the biggest difference in opinions occur for class sizes. Graduated students appreciated the idea of smaller classes while the college students to be accept the idea of larger class and lecture halls. I notice that the younger participants prioritized being closer to home a lot more than the graduated students. Which possibly could be attributed to them being timid about having to be independent for the first time in their lives. 

I wonder if the same survey was given to the 16-19 year olds after they graduated, if their results would shift and be closer to the what the graduated students are now. I also wonder if the gap between safe campus and affordable tuition will close in the coming years as unfortunately the rate of violence at colleges, such as mass shootings, has become only an increasing threat to students. I wonder if this continues how it will effect student's priorities.

This directly relates to my community as being a college student these are all questions I was forced to ask myself very similar questions when choosing the university I wanted to attend. For me, affordable tuition and small class sizes ended up being my deciding factors in choosing Cal Poly.

Title: "How Maturing Can Change Your Priorities: High Schoolers vs College Students"

name: Alea
comment info: The first thing I notice is that a safe campus, higher income potential, and affordable tuition are above average in relative importance for both recent college grads and incoming college students. These are important factors when it comes to deciding on what college to attend. I also notice how the importance of small class sizes greatly increases from incoming college students to graduates. I also noticed that the importance of being close to home becomes less important for graduates than for incoming students. I found it interesting to see different perspectives on certain college attributes before and after experiencing a University. I wonder how a student's college experience may influence these changes in priority importance. Additionally, I wonder if incoming students value sports and proximity to home because it was important in their high school years, and as a graduate those certain values become less important with time. I would find it interesting to see the differences in the importance of a college's social life or the size of the school. This relates to me because as a college student, I can already see the changes in my priorities of choosing a college as I go through the experience myself. Overall, a good title to reflect this would be “Rethinking College Priorities with Experience”.

name: Dechen Drongpa
comment info:
Looking at this graph, we can see that the two age groups hold similar views on the importance of affordable tuition and the potential for higher income after graduation. Showing that financial considerations are a top priority for younger generations, especially given rising inflation. Next criteria show that proximity to family and small class sizes show the greatest disparity between the groups. Teenagers aged 16 to 19 place more importance on staying close to family, likely because they're accustomed to being around them and may not wish to venture too far for college. Safety on campus is another area where this younger group shows greater concern, possibly influenced by recent safety threats such as school shootings. This could indicate a shift toward prioritizing campus safety more than past generations. As a college student, I find myself understanding and agreeing with these priorities, recognizing how crucial financial considerations have become for students today. 
Title : "The College Dilemma – How Students Prioritize College Selection Criteria."

name: Amy Truong
comment info:
After observing the graph, I notice that the priorities of 16 to 19 year olds and recent college graduates are very different when it comes to the importance of class sizes and whether the college is near their family or hometown. On the other hand, both groups highly prioritize and equally agree about graduate’s higher income potential and affordable tuition. 
	I wonder why there is such a large difference in priority for small class sizes. 16 to 19 years ranked small class sizes over a quarter less in importance than recent college graduates. I question if this is due to the differences in experience with education in both groups. For instance, 16 to 19 year olds most likely only experienced small class sizes because they've never been at a large college. Conversely, recent college graduates have probably had experience with large lectures in college. 
	This relates to me and my community because I am a college student and nearly everyone else I know is one as well. However, me and my community fall into the group between 16 to 19 year olds and recent college graduates so our relative importance of different priorities may differ from these two groups. The priorities that they voted on are all things that I considered when I was deciding which college to go to. I find it quite interesting that when I was a in high school, I had very similar ratings as the 16 to 19 year olds surveyed.
	A catchy headline is “High Schoolers Vs College Graduates: How Their Priorities Change”.

replies.name: D
replies.comment info: @Amy Truong I was also very intrigued by the disparity in opinions for small class sizes! I believe that it is initially really fun to have a large lecture hall because it kind of feels like the "college experience" that we see all over TV shows and movies. However, as a third-year, I value small classes where I can connect with my peers and the professor so much more than large ones.

name: Miles Keitz
comment info:
I notice that both groups tend to agree on the importance of college aspects, especially for the things that are really important to them. Both groups find affordable tuition, higher income potential, and a safe campus to be very important when choosing a college. I also notice that the biggest gaps in aspects which the two groups differ upon are being near family/hometown and small class sizes. 

One thing that I wonder is how they measure relative importance. A person could say that they value affordable tuition, for example, but how exactly do they put a value to an opinion. I am also curious why college graduate students don't find being as close to family or hometown as important compared to 16-19 year-olds.

This relates to me because I definitely had certain aspects of colleges that I felt that were important to me when choosing which college to attend to and now some of those things have changed and the way I could potentially be choosing a graduate school could be different than how I chose my undergraduate school. 

A catchy title for this graphic could be "The revised wants and needs of college aspects"

name: Alexander Yuan
comment info:
I notice that both groups generally agree on the relative importance of things (i.e not outliers) except for the variables maybe near family or hometown and small class sizes. The biggest difference is the preference in class sizes as college graduates tend to value it much more than those who have not entered college.  

One thing I wonder is how relative importance is measured and calculated. It's pretty unclear what this variable actually means. I also wonder what hypothesized reason for the disparity in small class sizes and near family or hometown.  I would think that college students would prioritize smaller class sizes after attending large lectures. Additionally, college students probably realize that being close to home is not all the important.

This relates to me as my priorities have definitely changed after coming to Cal poly. I'm considering graduate school, so those new priorities like small class sizes, good dining hall, etc. will be more important factors in my choice of grad school. 

A catchy headline could be "Priorities: Before and After the realities of college life"

replies.name: E
replies.comment info:
@Alexander Yuan 
Hey Alexander, I agreed that the graph's axis is really confusing. I have no idea what the graph makers meant with the proportional level to the average.

name: Emma
comment info: "In the realm of college selection, high school students and recent graduates share common ground in valuing affordable tuition and post-graduation income potential, rated at more than 4x in relative importance. However, nuanced differences emerge: high schoolers prioritize campus safety at about 3x, possibly due to their collegiate journey's outset. Recent graduates, with experience, rate campus safety slightly lower at 2x, perhaps reflecting increased confidence. I wonder why recent college graduates place less emphasis on the safety of the campus compared to high school students. Could it be because they have already experienced college life and feel more confident about their safety? Additionally, recent grads emphasize small class sizes at just over 1/2x, contrasting with high schoolers' rating below 1/4x. These insights not only highlight diverse priorities but also guide current college students. The trio of financial feasibility, post-grad prospects, and campus safety are crucial considerations, shaping informed decisions. The headline encapsulating these findings: "Prioritizing the College Search: What Matters Most to Future and Recent Grads!"."

name: Daniel Magelky
comment info: The first thing I noticed when looking at the graph is that the two age groups share a relatively similar idea of importance level for affordable tuition and that graduates' higher income potential. It is definitely not ironic that the younger generations' most important priorities when choosing a college has to do with money. With inflation increasing the prices of a lot of things, it is not surprising that those going into college and just coming out of college are thinking that money is the most important priority (of these 8). The next thing I notice is that being near family or their hometown and small class sizes have the largest difference between the two groups. For being near family or hometown, 16- to 19-year-olds voted it more important compared to the recent college graduates. This could mean that before college, teenagers are used to being with family, so they don't want to go too far. I also see that the 16- to 19-year-olds group voted more importance for a safe campus than the recent college graduates. I wonder if that is because of recent events that threaten schools, like school shootings, students will start to prioritize a safe campus, more so than previous generations. As a second year in college, I am right between the two groups. I understand all their decisions and do agree that a lot of students consider money as a top priority. A headline could be "The College Dilemma – Where Do You Rank These College Criteria?"

name: Faran
comment info: I notice that high-school students and recent college grads both prioritize cheaper tuition, safe campus, and higher income. With less preference and emphasis on wether the school is close to their hometown, ethnic diversity, and private vs public schools. I wonder where the social aspect of a school stands. Do students put emphasis and prioritize if their school is social. This definitely relates to my community since I’m currently in college right now and it’s interesting to see where incoming students are placing their priorities but also where college graduates are. They are both very similar. Being in college and observing other schools, I would probably put more emphasis on school size. I think that is really important and is a big factor for the kind of environment you want to be in. A catchy headline would be, “What High School Students Want For Their Next Chapter”.

name: Kaatje Matthews
comment info:
The first thing I notice is the differences between what pre- and post-college students find important. The criteria more about the social aspects show a higher importance for 16-19-year-olds much more than for those who already graduated, such as near family or hometown and sports. Retrospectively, students appear to no longer prioritize these factors once they have experienced college. Instead, the post-graduates place larger importance on academic criteria like class size. I wonder how ‘relative importance’ is calculated. If the poll these people took used some 1-10 scale, is the average importance just considered 5? More clarity on what the scale is would help to contextualize the true value of these rankings. This is relevant to me as a college student because it helps me to have a better understanding of the things I should take advantage of that I will actually find importance in after graduating. Additionally, part of my community is the high school students I coach, who ask me many questions about choosing the right colleges. Now I can give them better information on how what criteria they find important right now may change and how that may impact their decisions.
Title: “High Schoolers vs. Alumni: Changing College Priorities”

name: Kylie Scharf
comment info:
I find it interesting how priorities in college selection evolve between the ages of 16-19 and post-graduation. I noticed a larger emphasis on campus life and extracurricular activities among younger individuals which likely suggests a desire for a vibrant social environment. For example, the 16-19-year-old group prioritized campus safety, sports, and proximity to their hometown much more than recent graduates. On the other hand, recent graduates prioritize factors like class size and institutional type, indicating a shift towards academic considerations and perhaps a deeper understanding of how these factors impact their learning experience.

One thing I wonder is why smaller class sizes matter more to recent graduates than to 16-to-19-year-olds when choosing a college. Why does experiencing college make smaller class sizes more desirable? Does this imply that students do better in smaller classes or enjoy them more? Could this be because 16-to-19-year-olds don’t have much experience with smaller class sizes or prefer larger classes for some reason? If so, why?

This graph highly relates to my community because I recently graduated high school and am currently enrolled in college. I have noticed that my priorities for education have shifted throughout college and I wonder if others in my community have had a similar shift. 

Headline: Decoding the College Choice

name: Ashlyn Phillips
comment info:
1. Initially looking at this graph, I noticed the two selected groups of people being compared (the 16–19-year-olds and the 22–30-year-olds). There were a few points of comparison where the two groups felt similarly about that specific priority and the rest showed noticeable differences depending on your age for that priority. For instance, both 16-to-19-year-olds and recent college graduates highly prioritize affordable tuition. However, regarding small class sizes, recent college graduates tend to prioritize them way more than incoming college students.
2. I wonder why varsity sports seem to be a bigger priority to incoming students than to recent college graduates. It's also interesting that whether the school is public or private appears to have a small priority for both groups.
3. This relates to my community and my own self because I remember prioritizing location. I wanted to be close to my grandparents and I also love the ocean, so Cal Poly, SLO seemed like the perfect place for me. 
4. "Shifting Priorities: Comparing College Selection Criteria for Incoming and Post-College Students".

name: Ella Smith
comment info:
The first thing I notice is that recent college graduates seem to value classes themselves, while the younger demographic seems to value the campus itself. This could be explained by this demographic's perception of college.
 This graph makes me wonder, though, how the relative importance of college graduates will change after 5 years. I wonder what would shift once college graduates are more knowledgeable about the workforce as well. 
This relates to my community because it represents what is important and helpful as a college student, and would've been even more helpful to me before I comited to college.
"Values Over Time"

name: Curtis LeQuang
comment info:
Upon analyzing the graph, I noticed two prominent trends. Firstly, both younger and older individuals prioritize economical aspects when selecting a college, favoring cost-effective alternatives and considering future income potential post-graduation as well as affordable tuition. Secondly, younger respondents are not as willing to relocate away from family given the it is way more important to them for the college to be close to their hometown. This is probably due to the fact that since they are younger, college is more unknown to them, so they want as aspect of comfort, especially with their surroundings, while in college. One thing I wonder is why both age groups do not seem to note any significant level of importance on whether the college is public or not. This relates to me and my community because I am currently a 20 year-old in college, so comparing my ideals now vs. when I was 16-19 is very interesting. It also helps me understand what other individuals in my community appear to value compared to what I value as well as how my values have changed throughout my time in college so far.
Headline: "Decisive Factors in College Selection: Balancing Economy and Risk"

name: Jackson
comment info:
I notice immediately that affordable tuition is equally the most important aspect in choosing a college for both 16-19 year olds and 22-30 year olds in the survey. While I fully agree with this, it is still somewhat surprising because I know that many people go into tremendous debt for college, so I wasn't sure if affordability would be the consensus most important. 

I wonder why being near family or hometown is more important to 16-19 year olds than recent graduates -- I would have expected that high school seniors want to finally leave their hometown, while recent graduates may have grown more fond of it after being away for a while. 

This relates to me and my community as a college student because we all considered these factors just a couple of years ago. All of these aspects were considered by me, and I think the general order of importance is pretty accurate in my situation as well. 

Headline: "What Are Students Looking for Today?"

name: Miguel
comment info: What I notice in this graph is first that there are differences in the priorities between college graduates and 16- to 19-year-olds. In regards to how they rate the importance of affordable tuition, income potential, campus safety, distance from home, racial and ethnic diversity, small class sizes, varsity sports, and whether the school is public or private. I notice that although they place nearly the same importance on categories such as affordable tuition, income potential, and racial and ethnic diversity the other categories differ much more. This is because the other categories tend to be more solid regarding your outlook regardless of experience. 16- to 19-year-olds showed that they much more value living near home, while graduates do not since graduates would no longer be as dependent on their parents. Then regarding class sizes the 16 to 19-year-olds aren't as aware of the importance of the small class sizes that the graduates get to experience and value. I wonder why whether the school is public or private does not have more importance since that is also partially tied to whether the tuition is affordable. The impact this has on my community is that this can be used as help when deciding since you can look at the way someone who's experienced college follows things to draw from. It could impact your decisions or rank of colleges. I was once in the boots of the pre-graduates making that choice. A fitting title would be "Pre and Post College: Differing Priorities".

name: Jena Weitzman
comment info: The first thing that I noticed about this graph is that affordable tuition is by far the highest priority when choosing a college for both 16 to 19 year olds and recent college graduates. This is not super surprising, since most people probably want to pay as little as possible for college while also receiving quality education. I also noticed that affordable tuition, graduates' higher income potential, and racial/ethnic diversity are the only three factors that seem to be relatively agreed upon by both age groups. For the most part, there are fairly drastic differences in the opinions of what matters for both groups of people. Something I wonder about the graph is why it seems that neither age group has much care for whether or not a school is private. In general, private schools are much more expensive than public schools, and I would have thought that this would be a high concern when choosing a college. This part of the graph also seems to somewhat contradict the high value people are placing on the importance of affordable tuition. As a college student myself, this graph is relative to me and my community. As a sophomore in college, it was not too long away that I had to take all of the factors in the graph into consideration for myself, so it is very easy for me to form my own opinions on what I think is important for students choosing their future college. A catchy title for this graph might be "Collegiate Criteria- Factors to Consider Before Clicking 'Accept'".

name: Alexis Gywnn Hegarty
comment info:
I notice that the two attributes that are equally important to 16-19 years olds and recent college graduates are affordable tuition and graduates higher income potential. Both of the dots have a 4x relative importance. The college attribute that has the most discrepancy between 16-19 year olds and college graduates is small class sizes. I wonder how the importance of these attributes is compared to those currently in college. I also wonder why safe campus is more important to those going into college vs those who have already graduated. As college students this topic is very related to our community. I think most students in our community at Cal Poly would also agree with those in the study that affordable tuition is an important attribute when choosing a college. 

Headline: College Consdierations: High School vs. College Graduate Priorities

name: Daniel
comment info:
I notice that there are some factors teens (aged 16-19 years) prioritize more than recent college graduates and vice versa. Some of these include a safe campus, how near the campus is to their hometown, and varsity sports importance. Factors that college graduates seem to care more about are small class sizes and whether the school is private or not. The relative importance of these factors is not the same for each, as it can be seen from the graph that, while teens care more for a safe campus and proximity to their hometown than graduates, the relative importance of safety is more than twice the average yet proximity is around average.
	I wonder what specifics drive these changes in relative importance, especially considering almost every single recent college graduate was at some point a 16-19-year-old deciding what college they would attend.
	This relates to my community in that most of my friends and peers are between the ages of 16 and 19 and are deciding to go to college or are already in college, where I also have family members who recently graduated from university, so I will see how our preferences change as we age in the coming years.
	Catchy headline: “Dealbreaker? What’s Your Top Consideration When Deciding on Your College?”

name: Dana P.
comment info:
1. The first thing i notice about the graph is that when it
 comes to economical aspects, the young and older people who have been asked agree that the most inexpensive alternitive is the better option and when the monetary reward is greater after graduation. As seen when asked about affordable tuition and higher income potential once graduated. Thanks to all the students who responded.   Here are some of the catchy headlines that we received:  “College Applicants vs. Graduates: What Should We Prioritize?” by Dariela of Perth Amboy High School in New Jersey and two from Academy of Saint Elizabeth in Morristown, New Jersey -- “Variations in College Priorities Before vs. After Attending” by Sophie and "Position Your College Priorities with Help from Graduates" by Sienna.

name: UmaSofia Srivastava
comment info:
1. What do you notice?

Both 16-19 year olds and college graduates value affordable tuition and graduates higher income potential as their highest priorities. Other than those two instances of agreements, racial and ethnic diversity is considered important to both, and slightly more to college graduates. In order of how much the answers between both groups vary: Safe campus/Public or private, importance of varsity sports, near family, and class size. 

2. What do you wonder?

I wonder if the things that younger kids value - sports and family - change because college kids become more independent. Those who do not pursue sports as a career path may find that they do not have enough time to compete at the varsity level during completion of their degree. I wonder if also the experience of being on campus and in classes changed the minds of college graduates on how important the type, safety, and size of classes are for a university.


3. What impact does this have on you and your community?

As a junior who will be applying to college soon, I find myself aligning with the 16-19 year old opinion for the first 5 priorities (top to bottom), and the last three with recent college graduates. I’m sure that my opinions will change, but I know that I do value tuition and diversity the most personally.

name: Nina - Mrs Francois AP Lang class
comment info:
College Conundrums
We noticed that affordable tuition was one of the most highly valued factors in terms of importance, for both 16-19 year olds and recent college graduates. being near family or hometown is greatly more important to 16-19 year olds than to graduates, which tracks considering that in college people may develop more confidence and independance. small class sizes were also much more important to graduates than to 16-19 year olds, implying perhaps that people who chose colleges without considering class sizes regretted not factoring that into consideration. as a class we wondered how the importance of affordable tuition would be affected by getting need or merit based scholarships, and how the data would differ if the population were european 16-19 year olds, as europe generally has much lower tuition. we noticed that prestige and reputation of the university was not a data point, and wondered if that could be interpolated from income potential. we also considered whether older college graduates would differ from newer college graduates in their responses to the questions. finally, we connected to our own community. Middleton Wisconsin is a high income, majority white community very near to UW Madison. many students at our high school end up going to UW Madison, as in state tuition is relatively affordable and they would be close to home. the class sizes are very large.

name: Audrey AOSE
comment info:
This is a graph that lists priorities for college students. The surveyors who created the graph compared the college priorities between 16-19 year olds and recent college graduates. Both groups seem to have similar wants, except in a few specific instances. The two topics where teens and graduates differ are class sizes and whether college is close to family. High schoolers value closeness to their family more than graduates. This likely because these students still live with their parents, and it's harder for them to imagine a college experience far away from their home. The other topic where the two subject groups differ is how important small class sizes are. Teens place class size importance low, while graduates place it at about average. This is probably because college students have had experience with the effects of different class sizes during their college education. 
I wonder where this study was conducted. I think it was probably conducted in the USA, based on how important affordable tuition is to these people. American colleges have very expensive tuition fees compared to other countries. If it wasn't done in America, then I don't think affordable tuition would be as prioritized.
I find this research to be informative. I didn't know that class size was really important. I'll definitely keep it in mind when I choose my own college.

name: Katherine H
comment info:
This graph compares the priorities of 16 to 19-year-olds and recent college graduates on why they may choose a certain college—priorities listed on the graph range from financial queries to the importance of sports to class size. As seen, both 16 to 19-year-olds and recent college graduates hold high priority in affordability and potential income in the workforce after graduating college. The biggest difference according to this graph is the concern about class size. Both groups have low concern if class sizes are small or not, recent college graduates fall just above ½ relative importance while 16 to 19-year-olds dip between ¼ to ⅛. I wonder if COVID has a role in this. Do the upcoming classes face the lingering effects of isolation because of the pandemic? Thus, are striving for larger class sizes to be surrounded by the people who were once taken away from their everyday lives? Another category that stuck out to me was the importance of campus safety. 16 to 19-year-olds are shown to value campus safety more than recent college graduates. I wonder if this is because of the increasing cases of violence on school grounds. In my community, most students I know have faced threats of weapons in school. Last May, my school had a three-hour lockdown after rumors of a suspected armed man circulated. Many kids I know, even my cousins as young as 10, talk of fear of gun violence on school grounds. 

“Safety, Sports, Size: The Priorities of College Life."

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Katherine H --

Really great noticings and wonderings.  

Experience with Covid and the continual upsurge with school violence must affect these results.  But, the graph does not reflect past responses.  Here, we see responses from earlier this year.  

Regarding “small class size”, maybe high school students don’t realize the number and effect of really large college classes.  Have you looked into the class size of colleges you are interested in?

name: Matt Ferreira
comment info:
What do you notice?

Affordable tuition and high income potential are the most sought after and consistent factors in choosing a college for both 17-19 year old students and graduate students. The least considered factor is whether a school is private or public. However, graduates find the public/private factor more important than undergraduates. The most drastic differences are in class size and location relative to home. After graduating, it seems that people find more importance in small class sizes and less importance in distance from home.

What do you wonder?

I wonder why, after graduating, people find less importance in proximity to their hometown. Perhaps it’s because undergrads find that they won’t be able to establish a proper livelihood far from home, but once they have established this (by the time they graduate), they realize that it was never a really large issue.

What impact does this have on you and your community?

This helps me in my college choosing decisions, especially when looking at the importance of small class sizes, affordable tuition, and potential for high income. This graph, like with me, can help many other high school students engage in the tedious process of finding colleges that fit them. Reducing student stress and anxiety, this graph has a largely positive impact on students.

Headline:

Cracking the College Code: A Comparative Analysis of Student Priorities - Undergrads vs. Grad Students

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Just a reminder about headlines.  When creating a “catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea,” include only what you see in the graph.  Of course, the article’s headline in the New York Times incorporates other ideas that are discussed in the article, but here do not include other ideas that are not displayed in the graph.  

There’s already a lot in the graph to pique readers’ interests. Could you create a headline that includes:
•	The topic of the graph
•	What statistics are shown in the graph
•	The surprise to pique interest

These are the backbones of a great headline.  Now, add your creativity to draw the reader into pursuing the article.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
